text: Two FIFTEEN year-old BOYS stand outside this rough, inner city school on a cold, rainy morning. They are CONOR and DARREN. Conor is a middle class kid with a posh accent. Darren is a local boy, with a tough Dublin accent. They are elbowed by passing STUDENTS entering the school gates. Some of them mince past them, implying that they a gay- These two are outsiders. Conor will be handsome when he grows up. While most of th other boys have standard issue tight haircuts, Conor’s is long and tousled. He sports two black eyes, making him lo like a panda. Darren has acne, buck teeth, braces and bifocals. His face is a mess. They are both looking across the road. We don’t see at wh
Who's she?
I don’t know. She’s always there.
She’s beautiful.
Yeah. Good luck. She doesn’t speak to anyone. Stuck-up cow.
Who says?
Ciaran Mackie from third year said he tried to get her digits.
(confused) You mean her number? (CONTINUED)
Yeah. No luck. He said she has a boyfriend who’s a drug dealer. She's not interested any of the boys in the school.
Oh yeah? Why’s she standing there then? Darren shrugs. Conor takes a breath, sets off, crossing t road.

We track with him over his shoulder, arriving at a 16 yea old GIRL, who is standing on the stoop of a HOUSE, an unl cigarette dangling from her purple lips. Conor stands in front of her. She has a great look: lots of black. Good makeup. Back-co hair. Early ‘80s teen-chic. She’s ahead of her time, and anything but ordinary.
Need a light?
No. I’m trying to give up.
Cool. I don’t have any matches anyway. Silence. He doesn’t go away.
Why aren’t you at school?
I don’t go to school. (beat) I’m a model.
Cool. Like, for magazines, and stuff?
I’m going to London soon. Just waiting for my portfolio shots. There’s no real work for models in Dublin, you know.
Yeah. I know. (CONTINUED)
He thinks.
Oh yeah, I meant to ask- do you want to be in a video? For my band?
You’re in a band?
Yes. And we need a girl for it. There’s like a story. It’s called a “Story-Board” video. You could be the girl. In the story. If you’re free. Have you been in a video before?
No. (beat) Is that a problem?
I hope not. I’1l ask the producer.
Who’s the producer?
That kid behind me. She looks over his shoulder, pulling onto Darren, who wav nonchalantly.
When are we shooting? I’m pretty busy.

Saturday after next. I can call you with the details. If I had your digits. She puts the cigarette away, taking out her pen. He produ his journal, handing it to her. She flicks through it, it full of thoughts and drawings.
Lyrics.
So if you’re in a band, sing me a song.
I’m not singing here. (CONTINUED)
What, you’ll have to sing in front of thousands of people. I’m just one. Sing.
What?
Sing anything off the radio. He reluctantly sings a hesitant but tuneful few lines fro popular song. She smiles. She writes down her number on t cover. He smiles, turning back. Score.
We track back with him across the street as he approaches Darren, who can’t believe what he’s seen.
We need to form a band... Freeze Frame. A loud, energetic punk song crashes in on t track. SONG and titles run over:
A montage of news stories, rock videos, magazine covers, headlines. It's the early eighties, and it's Ireland. Mid through the worst recession since the 1950s.
Across the Irish sea, in London, news reports see Thatche waving to the crowds. City boys talk into early mobile telephones, getting into sports cars. Armani suits, and g cuff links.

But back in Ireland: bombs in the North, petrol queues in South. Deserted building sites, bricked-up buildings. Mor black and white, than London’s Technicolor. INT. CONOR’S KITCHEN - DAY We start to PULL OUT from an old TV set. The 9 o’clock ne is on. The volume turned down low.  INT. CONOR'’S KITCHEN (CONTINUOUS) - DAY We find ourselves in a large kitchen. High ceilings and rattling sash windows, in what 100 years ago was a fine Georgian home. Now, things are a little faded. The room i cold and unwelcoming. Very little on the shelves. A famil a budget. Sitting around the kitchen table are: Conor (no black eye yet), and his parents, PENNY and ROBERT, both in their mi forties. They’ve just finished a meal of Spag Boll. Thoug it’s more Spag than Boll. Penny fills up her glass of che supermarket wine. Robert picks his teeth with a toothpick He is drinking a whiskey and smoking. Penny checks her wa They are sitting in silence, as if waiting for something happen. Conor is wearing a woolly hat, and his coat, indo Card:

INT. CONOR'’S KITCHEN (CONTINUOUS) - DAY Finally, the sound of someone racing down the stairs from above. The door opens and BRENDAN, (20), tumbles into the room carrying an ash tray, glass of wine, tobacco pouch, rolling papers and matches. He sits down at the vacant se beside his brother. Brendan has long hair, and a moustach He’s handsome.
This meeting has been called to order. Pray proceed. He lights a cigarette.
Okay, so we wanted to talk about finances. Penny?
What? Go ahead.
(to his brother) This is going to be heavy.

Well, as you might have noticed- your mother and I are really struggling at the moment, like the rest of the country. I haven’t had a single commission this year. Your mother is on a three day week. It doesn’t look like it’s going to get much brighter. (CONTINUED)
He knocks back his drink. The kids wait for what’s comin next.
So we’ve had a look through the accounts, and we see quite a significant saving if we were to alter the education situation.
What “education situation”?
(intuiting) He means your school. They’re taking you out of school.
(excited) What?!
We're not taking you out of school. We're transferring you from one school to another.
Why!?
We have to make some cuts to the budget. I’d suggest taking your brother out of college, but he’s already dropped out of his own volition.
(raising a glass) Thank you Dad.
Cuts? I’m already wearing three jumpers, indoors. And a hat. I read by candlelight! And it’s the 1980s. I’m like Tiny Tim up there! Brendan laughs.
Don’t act so entitled. I grew up in a council house with five brothers.
(mock surprised) Really? Tell us about that dad. For the first time ever. (CONTINUED)
Silence.
A school that’s close by. So there’s no transport costs. You can cycle in. And you can get lunch back here. There’s two savings already! It’s a non-fee paying school.
Those Jesuits are far too soft on you anyway.
The Jesuits have a long history of education.
So do the Christian Brothers.
Who are the Christian Brothers?
The Christian Brothers, Conor, are a order of the Catholic Church, appointed in the education, formation, and beating of their young charges.
Oh be quiet Brendan! Six years at the hands of the Jesuits yourself, and look at what they did for you!
Well they didn’t beat me.
Brendan! Cut that out. Synge Street is a perfectly reputable school. You’1l settle in in no time.
You can’t just change in the middle of the year. Just when I’m making friends and settling in. This could scar me. Long-term!
Just deal with this, Conor. You know what the Christian Brother's motto is? “Viriliter Age”. That means “Act Manly”. This meeting is over. (CONTINUED)

Brendan gets up. He squeezes Conor’s shoulder, big broth style, and exits. His parents go about their business. We push in on Conor, alone. EXT. CONOR’S HOUSE (CONTINUOUS) - DAY The door slams as Conor exits his house, zipping up his jacket. He marches down the driveway. He wears brown cord with a slight flare to them. Leather shoes. Jumper. This is a leafy suburb of Dublin. Middle class, safe, protected. But Conor’s house stands out. It has seen bett days. It needs a new coat of paint, and the garden could with a mow. A car is parked in the driveway, but hasn’t b used in a good while. Three push bikes are leaning agains the gate instead. He walks up the street with his hands in his pockets.

This is a large sports ground in a leafy Jesuit school. N red brick buildings, very peaceful. It’s the weekend, and students are practicing track, rugby, cricket. A big copp beech tree shades the Cricket Training net. Conor is at the wicket, bat in hand. Two FRIENDS are play with him. They all speak with posh, South-side accents.
So guys, I’m not coming back after the break.
The hell? Why?
The old pair are moving me to a different school.
Dicks. Why?
They say they have no money. The ball whizzes past him. He misses by a mile, throwing the bat in frustration. They take a break.
But we still hang out, yeah?
Totally man. (CONTINUED)
At weekends and stuff. Right?
Absolutely. So where are you going? Conlets? Conor doesn’t respond.
Gonzaga?
Synge Street. His friends exchange looks after they see he’s not joking
What?? It can’t be that bad? One of them mock-hugs him.
Seriously bro, it’s been nice knowing you. His friends laugh. We hold on Conor, the gravity of his situation sinking in.

Conor is sitting in a cosy, large office. Across from him his history teacher, and headmaster, FATHER WAITS (late 5 Fr. Waits smokes a pipe, sitting on the edge of his desk. is prematurely grey, and has a warm, understanding appearance. His SECRETARY, a heavy woman in her fifties, in an anteroom, typing, off.

We'll be sorry to be losing you. Synge Street was a fine school in its day. It has a poor reputation now, but I’m sure that’s exaggerated. The Christian Brothers can be a little tough to my mind, but they get the work done.
No more rugby. No cricket practice. Debating. School plays??
They’1l have their own extracurricular activities I suspect. (CONTINUED)
Yeah, like flick knife practice. And corporal punishment.
I’m sure that’s not true.

I've heard it is. I can’t do corporal punishment. I’m light- boned. Father Waits laughs. Though Conor is wise-cracking, he’s clearly genuinely nervous. Father Waits gets up, putting a hand on Conor’s shoulder walking him to the door.
You'll be fine, Conor. Trust me. You know what’s gotten us to where we are today, us humans? One quality? They pause at the open door.

Adaptability. He winks, shaking Conor’s hand. Conor shuffles off down t corridor. Father Waits looks over to his secretary who has been listening. He makes a doubtful expression. She nods in agreement.

A church on a school campus. 30 choir boys are at choir practice on the alter. They are dressed in their own clot There is no congregation. It’s Saturday rehersal. They si BACH. We slowly ZOOM in to Conor, who is standing on the edges the back row. He sings, but is lost in thought. A TEACHER is conducting them.

Conor walks past Synge Street School that evening. The ga are open. The deserted school looms grey and forboding in dusk sky. He pushes the gate open and enters, looking aro Litter rolls like tumbleweed across the pot-holed yard. Stripped-down bicycle frames remain locked to the outdoor bike shed. Old windows rattle in the wind. (CONTINUED)

The walls read like a tabloid newspaper: “IRA” “BRITS OUT “JENNY GREEN IS A SLUT ” are among the headlines. The playing field of his previous school is another world INT. BRENDAN’S ROOM - EVENING Back in his house, we are in Brendan's attic lair. As far away from the rest of the house as possible. This small r is a shrine to music and art. And hash. We have numerous ash trays. A homemade hammock. Posters o bands on the walls. Shelves of books on pop art, philosop and music. A poster of SIGMUND FREUD on the wall next to bed. A voice bubble has been drawn in, saying “It’s all y mother’s fault”. A portable TV on a box. An acoustic guitar with two strin But most importantly, a huge collection of Vinyl. Proudly alphabetized. The only thing so in Brendan's life. The windows are blacked out with hanging blankets, and th lighting is low; easy on the eternally stoned eye. Brendan sits in his huge, collapsed armchair in a mist of marijuana smoke, a king of his own domain. He is taking a drag from one. The door is ajar. Outside, Conor knocks.
You in there?
Where else would I be?
I don’t know. The kitchen?
I’m in here. Conor enters, leaning against the wall by the door.
(sage-like) You appear troubled, my young friend. Conor nods his head.
Sit. Share your woes. Conor sits on the edge of his brother’s bed. (CONTINUED)
You start tomorrow? Conor nods his head.
You'll be fine. You just have to find a way of distracting the thugs from noticing you.
How do I do that?
How would I know?
I feel like I’m going to prison.
You are. In a way. All institutions are prisons. You do realize that this is just part of the bigger picture? This school move?
How do you mean?
I’m pretty sure they’re splitting up. I hear them rowing, in the middle of the night.
Do you? Why aren’t you asleep? Brendan just laughs at this, as if sleep would be ridicul
There'll be plenty of time for that. He takes another drag, and then instinctively goes to pas to Conor. But then realizes, pulling it back.
Oh, no, you’re tiny. He stands up, taking the record that has been playing quietly. Replaces it carefully, and searches for somethin else.
..-and this is just the start of a process. They start moving you around. Soon the electricity will be cut off. The bailiff will come. The house will be sold. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
The cave is under threat, brother. From monsters. Conor is genuinely concerned.
What monsters? Brendan finds a record that is pertinent, opening it, and carefully rubbing his sleeve off the vinyl.
Oh, just the three-headed monster of Fear, Infidelity, Ego, Materialism.
That’s a four-headed monster.
The things that are destroying their marriage. And now YOU'RE being tested. This is YOUR time. I had my time.
And what happened?

(beat, a thousand thoughts in a blink of an eye) This is a great chance for you. To break that cycle of shit. That school would have turned you into a doctor, or a lawyer. “Must make money, must make money”. Conor listens attentively, if a little confused.

(off his look of confusion) That was a robot I just did there. Who wants to be a robot? Except R2D2? Who knows what this new prison will do for you, my little friend! (beat) You're on a hero’s journey. How are you going to fare? He puts on the record he’s been looking for. The needle m the vinyl with a comforting crunch. A loud, heavy metal s from the late seventies. The room rocks. Brendan smiles at his younger brother, “y feeling me??” (CONTINUED)
Hard cut.

Song playing loud. Monday morning. Almost in answer to his brother’s questio Conor walks into the gate of the school. Numerous kids ha gathered in packs. Conor has to walk a gauntlet of new fa Heads turn towards the newcomer. There is something of a stranger arriving at a new town in a Western. But this is Western, and the stomping song tells us so. Conor’s three quarter length smart coat and long curly hair draws laugh He is also carrying a soft, brown leather satchel, which doesn’t help. Kids smoke in circles. Kids spit on the ground. Further into the walk, a fight is just breaking out, anda small circle is gathering. Two boys beat it out. Bloody n and fists. Conor speeds up as he passes. He notices that above them, at a second story window, a BROTHER (50s), in black suit and white collar, is watching the fight down below. He does nothing about it. One KID has a dead RAT skewered on the end of a stick. He chases other kids around with it. He finally throws it at Conor. It hits him on the side of the head. Others laugh. The song ends as he enters the school. The back of his co is covered in spit. INT. CLASSROOM — DAY Conor sits in a large, drafty classroom, looking around. windows rattle in the wind. Worn, wooden floorboards underfoot. The desks are mismatched. Two kids per desk. T is a class of about 35 kids. BROTHER BARNABAS (70), in a black gown and white collar, writes Latin on the blackboard. Even with his hearing aid, he can’t hear kids chatting, laughing and fighting when his back is turned. Conor sits in the middle, amazed. To his left, at the bac class, a boy smokes a cigarette, blowing the smoke out th sash window beside him. To his right, two BOYS hold down another, as a fourth far in his mouth, closing it, and making him swallow. Another kid is getting an Indian ink tattoo: IRA, on his hand. (CONTINUED)

At the blackboard, Brother Barnabas takes a surreptitious swig from a hip flask, returning it under his gown. This guy should have been put out to pasture a long time ago. The door swings open, and the HEADMASTER enters silently, his morning rounds. The class stands up. Silence. He is t same Brother we saw watching the fight on the way in.
(as one) Good morning Brother Baxter. Brother Baxter surveys the room, landing on the blackboar
It’s French, brother Barnabas.
Hah?
You're teaching French. Not Latin. Brother Barnabas looks at the board, seeing that he is teaching Latin.
Oh. How modern. Brother Baxter speaks in a tough, no nonsense Dublin acce His bushy moustache suggests something of a military man.
Mind you, I'd be surprised if any of ye even knew where France is, not to mind speaking the language. Silence. Conor, who thinks this is an actual question, raises a hand.
Oh. Go on.
On the continent. Above Spain.
My my. And how do you know that?
My parents took us there. One summer. In the car. Other kids laugh, jealously.
You'll be the new lad then, from the Jesuits. (CONTINUED)
Yes.
Yes “Brother”. What’s your name.
Conor Lawlor. Laughter. Conor looks around, all eyes on him. Brother Ba is impressed.

Shut up! You could all take a leaf out of his book. Look at a map once in a while. Right Conor. Morning prayers are at a quarter to nine. Little break is ten minutes. At 11 o'clock. Big break is 45 minutes at 1 o'clock. The canteen is located below the P.E. Hall. They serve chips and bars. The lads will show you the ropes. Welcome.
Thank you.
As you were! He turns to go. But as he does, he sees Conor’s feet unde his desk. He pauses. Conor is wearing brown leather brogu Everyone else is wearing black shoes.
We have a strict, black shoe policy here, Mr. Lawlor. Your parents should have read it in the introductory rule book. Page 142. We'll let it go today, but from tomorrow on... He goes to exit again.
I don’t have black shoes, Sir. Brother Baxter pauses at the door. The class goes silent. is not used to being questioned like this.

Well, you’1l have to get a pair then. And report to me first thing in the morning with them. Good man. Brother Baxter exits. The class takes a sigh of relief. T kid who was smoking releases a lung-full of smoke. Brothe Barnabas goes back to teaching Latin. (CONTINUED)
Conor leans into the BOY sitting next to him, MICK MAHON, really tough kid with a buzz cut and a gold stud earring.
Sorry, but where did he say the restaurant was?
The wha?
The restaurant? The cafeteria?
You mean the canteen?
Yeah. Of course. Mick just shakes his head in amazement.
The “restaurant”. You’re not in France now, you bleedin spanner.

Little break. Kids play football with a punctured football. Others sit walls eating sweets. Conor wanders about on his own looki for the canteen. He passes by the alleyway towards the P. hall. From behind the bike sheds, a low whistle catches h attention. Down the alley way is a 15 year-old. He has a cigarette i his hand. He has a skin head. His uniform is dirty and to short for him. He wears scuffed loafers and a green bombe jacket.
Do you smoke, do you?
Oh. Occasionally. I’m not really a smoker. My brother is, and I sometimes take a little of his tobacco, if my friends are over. And my dad used to smoke a pipe. But he gave up.
Why are you telling me all this? Come on and we’ll have a smoke. Follow me. (CONTINUED)

Conor follows the kid, who enters a prefab marked TOILETS INT. THE BOY’S TOILET’S (CONTINUOUS) - DAY This is a stinking prefabricated building, with a row of urinals across from three cubicles. The floor is sticky a wet. Conor follows the KID in. He puts a cigarette in his mouth.
D’you want one?
Nah, I’m okay. I’1l just watch you. I've already had a couple this morning. The kid pulls a Black Widow catapult from inside his bomb jacket, and a large marble.
Did you ever see one these, did you? He loads it with the marble, and points it at Conor’s hea
I hear you're a queer.
What?
I hear you’re a little queer?
No. You must have me mixed up with someone else.
(scrutinizing him) I don’t think so. Dance.
What?
Dance. Like a queer. Conor doesn’t know how to deal with this.
Are you serious? The kid aims the catapult at a light bulb, and fires, hit it perfectly, re-loading and pointing it back at Conor. (CONTINUED)
Conor starts a merry jig. The KID watches for a while, hi catapult ready.
Now dance with your pants down.
What?
Get into that cubicle. And dance with your pants down. Conor stops dancing.
No.
What did you just say.
No, I’m not doing that. Silence. To his surprise, the kid disarms his catapult.
Okay. Bye Bye. Conor walks past him, exiting hurriedly, baffled.

Conor is in a basement building. No windows. It’s lit wit fluorescent lights. Kids of all ages muck about. There’s ping pong table with no net or bats. There’s a tuck shop candy bars and a dinner lady deep frying chips at a windo Music plays through a small ghetto blaster. Many kids are smoking. Conor heads for the tuck shop window, joining a rowdy que while searching for enough change in his pockets. He manages to get 25 pence together and exchanges it for Mars bar. As he turns to exit, the KID from the toilet is standing right behind him. He taps him on the shoulder. C turns around. People watch on, knowing that something is brewing. The KID lets Conor have it, right on the eye. It’s a good shot. People wince. Conor goes down on the ground. The KID picks up Conor’s Mars Bar and rips it open; takes bite and throws away the rest. He turns and swaggers off. People clear the way from him, keeping their distance. (CONTINUED)
The bell rings and everyone starts to shuffle off back to class, some of them step over Conor, laughing. As the room empties out, we hear a voice, off:
You should've just danced. Conor looks over his shoulder. DARREN (who we met in the title scene) is crossing over towards him, putting on his jacket.
Conor, now in the company of Darren, walks back towards h classroom, holding his eye.
So you were there? In the toilets?
I’ve a touch of the scutters. So I was in one of the cubicles all morning with the liquid shits. He smiles.
Darren’s the name. He goes to shake hands. Conor take his hand, hiding his reluctance.
Conor. Who is that psycho?
That's Barry Bray. He eats hair gel.
What?
Yeah. He ate a pot of hair gel in class once. No one knows why. The only problem now is, he’1l be out for your blood.
Why?
Because you’ve shown weakness.
How do you know him? (CONTINUED)
We hold on Conor, looking increasingly worried. Synge is certainly living up to its reputation.

He lives in the same flats as me. His ma and da are mad drug addicts. People say he was conceived on acid. And it got into his bloodstream. But don’t worry, you just need to come up with a plan for the year. A solution. Here. 21. Street He hands him a slip of paper from a plastic wallet. It re in marker: Darren Mulvey. Business solutions. Saint Teresa's Gardens. Flat 221. “Your problem is my solution!"
Call me any time.
There’s no number on it.
No, we don’t have a phone. Just call around. They arrive outside Conor’s class.
This is my class. Where are you?
Ah they kept me back a year. Or two. I can’t really read very well.
Right. How’s that going to work, in business?
(leaning in) I can read people. And you’re alright. But you won’t survive in here unless we deal with Barry.
What about telling the Brothers?
Hah! You could do that, yeah. Darren heads off, laughing. (CONTINUED)
Conor heads back into class. The door slams behind him wi menacing “SLAM” INT. CONOR’S HOUSE - NIGHT Penny stands in the hallway, shouting upstairs.

Bren! Conor! It’s on. Brendan exits his room quickly. He is carrying his drinki and smoking accoutrements. He passes Conor’s door as Cono exits. The two of them run downstairs. It’s like a fire drill.

Brendan and Conor burst into the sitting room. Their fath is sitting at the table drinking a whiskey. The collar of jacket is turned up, and he has a scarf on. In front of h a few architectural drawings, draftsman kit, sliding rule etc. He is sketching plans for a building that will never built. Numerous photographs of Brendan are framed and around the place. As a baby. A young boy. A handsome teenager. Etc. Brendan was the golden boy. Brendan turns on the TV as he and Conor take seats on the couch.
Can we turn on the fire?
No.

(off) It’s Thursday. It’s 7 o’clock. It’s Top of The Pops! Penny enters, sitting across from her husband, drinking a coffee. She is wearing a big cardigan. As the charts countdown for January starts, they are a family. Sort of.
“They can’t be here tonight as they’re in the USA, so instead, we have to go to... RIO. It’s Duran Duran!” (CONTINUED)
On the TV, the video for Duran Duran’s “Rio” begins. Cono glued to the screen as Brendan lectures on the clothes, video, song, and lyrics. Conor is an enthusiastic student

The jury is out on which way these guys will go. They’re a lot of fun, and John Taylor is one of the most proficient bass players in the UK right now, giving them a funky edge which I hope they'll go with. Look at this video! He laughs with glee as beautiful people aboard a yacht in Caribbean surround Simon LeBon. The band looks good. The girls are clad in bikinis. At the table, Robert looks back at his sketch. He scrunch up the sheets of paper angrily. Frustrated. Penny watches this.
Who am I kidding. Nothing’s getting built here for another ten years at least.
You don’t know that. He laughs, pouring a whiskey, and turning towards the TV.
Not exactly the Beatles, is it.
Oh, I’1l just start up the time machine so we can go BACK in time for dad. He sighs. Underwater, Simon LeBon drinks a pink cocktail underwater. The pink liquid mixes with the sea. Brendan laughs.
Well if that’s the future we’re all screwed. Look at him, he’s not even singing live!
It’s a video, Robert. It’s a piece of art. Everyone is making them now.
Yeah Robert. (CONTINUED)
(referring to Simon) He’s very attractive isn’t he?
You’re welcome to him.
Do you promise? On screen, a guy in the video plays a saxophone solo on a raft.
Wow, a saxophone solo.
That might date.
Why can’t they get them to play live? What are they hiding?

Because they’re in the USA, didn’t you hear him? And this lasts forever. It’s the perfect marriage of music and visuals. Short. To the point. Look at that... He points to the screen. Hedonism and fun, in Technicolor
What tyranny could stand up to that? Conor looks at the screen, transfixed. His brother has a point. Sort of.
That's because this is the tyranny.
Oh let’s not begin a philosophical argument Robert.
Why not?
Because you'll lose. This winds Robert up, who is up for a fight, but a stern shake of Penny’s head warns him off. (CONTINUED)
(quietly) .--and the thing about Barry Bray is, he’s probably a victim himself. Bullying is a cycle. Like with Dad. His dad undermined him, pissed on his dreams. So what do you expect.
Right.

So we gotta break the cycle. Right? Look at these guys- (referring to the band) Their dads fought in the Second World War! Wore flat caps and woolen underwear. Look at them now! On screen, Duran Duran are the epitome of ‘80s London: affluence, arrogance, and renewed confidence.
Barry Bray is more than likely gay. And he’s struggling with it. And holding you up in the toilets is all part of that.
Really?

Probably. It’s not a good school to be gay in, he’s suffering in there, same as you. But the only way to get him off your back is to understand him. To defeat him, you must firstly forgive him. He nods, sagely, returning to watching the TV. We hold on Conor thinking about this advice.

Conor walks into school. He is keeping a low profile, wal in by the wall as the madness carries on all around him. Up ahead, he runs into Brother Baxter. He looks him up an down. We TILT down to reveal... BROWN SHOES. Hold on Brother Baxter’s face. An inscrutable look. Deep shock that his warning would be ignored.  26. INT. BROTHER BAXTER’S OFFICE - MOMENTS LATER Brother Baxter sits behind his large desk in his office. little in this room, except a statue of the Virgin Mary, a cross. On the other side of the desk, Conor. Silence.
What’s going on, son?
About the shoes? Brother Baxter just nods.

Well, I brought it up with my mum. But she said we couldn't afford another pair of shoes at the moment. I bought these before I knew about the shoe colour policy here at Synge Street. But it’s not as if these are runners or something. They’re brown. They’re quite sensible.
I can see that. They’re very nice. Tasteful, as you say. But you see, they’re not black?
I’m not sure... What you want me to do. They’re shoes. They keep the rain out.
(nodding his head) Take them off.
What?

Seeing as you’re so fond of them. You can pick them up here at four o'clock every day until you comply with the rules of the school. Conor looks at him in disbelief. Is this really what’s go to happen now?
Close on a pair of stockinged feet. Conor walks down the corridor in his socks. Kids laugh. What is going on.  27.
Now Conor walks through puddles in the yard. His socks ar already developing holes.

Conor sits in art class. This class is made up of about twelve kids. Including Conor. There’s some interesting ar the walls. Conor rubs his feet together, trying to keep w MISS DUNNE (40s), sits on the corner of her desk. She has curvy figure, and a mane of dyed blonde hair. She has a Dublin accent. She has a scented candle lit on her desk. few flowers in a glass.
Right, so most of yiz picked this class because ye didn’t wanna do mechanical drawing. Am I right? Most people nod.
Yiz think art class will be a doddle? A chance to get a break in the day and scribble a few pictures in between other classes? A few lads nod in agreement.
Right, well you’re not completely off the mark. This gets a little laugh.

Art should be a break from the rest of the world. It should never be work. It’s kind of... therapy. But don’t think you're not going to learn something in here. I’m going to impart some information to ye, okay? So when you’re out with a girl at the National Gallery, you can look at a painting and SAY something about it. Okay? A few nods and mutterings of acceptance. Mick Mahon puts hand up.
I’1ll take you on a date to the National Gallery any day, miss. (CONTINUED)
Ah, thanks, Michael. But I have a fiance already.
Are you sure?
Positive. She puts on her glasses to get a closer look at Conor’s f under his desk.
What the hell is going on here?
Oh. I don’t have black shoes. So I have to leave my brown ones in Brother Baxter’s office every day until I get some. She shakes her head.

Conor enters the canteen in his bare feet. He looks aroun Up ahead in a little group, he sees Barry. He musters up courage, and approaches, tapping him on the shoulder. Bar Bray turns around. Other kids notice this.
Hey. I understand that you’re in pain. That there is a conflict within you. And that can’t be easy to deal with in this school. You publicly humiliated me. So now, I publicly forgive you. Barry Bray.
Conor now has the TWO black eyes of the opening scene. Da stands beside him. He marches off towards the GIRL across the street. We hol Darren this time. In a few moments, Conor returns:
We need to form a band...  29.
Conor and Darren stand at the front door of a small, run- cottage on a narrow lane way. They are not wearing their school uniforms. It’s out of school. Darren knocks on the knocker.

Eamon’s a genius. He can play every instrument known to man. His hobby is rabbits. After a while we hear footsteps thundering down the stair The door opens and EAMON (14), stands there. Eamon wears stone-washed denims, matching DENIM (!) jacket, a crew ne jumper, and white, dirty boot runners. He has curly hair, and wears steel-rim glasses. He sports wicked mullet.
Hey Eamon. What you doing?
Nothing. I was just feeding me new bunny. Howareya Darren.
Cool. This is Eamon. Eamon, this is Conor. He’s new in the school, and he’s putting together a band.

So? INT. EAMON’S LIVING ROOM - MOMENTS LATER Eamon’s small living room has been transformed into a ban rehersal space. In a semicircle in the corner of the room a drum kit, guitar amp, keyboard, and microphone. Conor l about, impressed.
Wow! Where did you get all this gear??
Me da’s in a covers band. Weddings, parties, pubs. Close up on the logo on the kick drum: “EAZY LIVIN’” with some glittery stars.
Eamon can play every instrument known to man, can’t you Eamon? (CONTINUED)
Probably.
Show him. FOUR VERY QUICK SHOTS: Eamon plays the bass guitar, slapp The drums. The guitar, soloing. And the keyboard, playing jazz.

Wow. So/ But Eamon isn’t finished. SIX more very quick shots. Eamon is playing an African Balaphone. Next, he’s playing an Indian flute. Then the Uilleann pipes. Then a shaker. Then a Conga drum. Finally he is done. He’s clearly something of a prodigy.
What do you play yourself?
(thinking on his feet) I’m more of a singer. Eamon waits for him to go on.
And I write songs. Well, I mean, lyrics. Words. But I haven’t put them to music yet.
So what do yous want from me?
We want to hire your instruments.
(interrupting) No way. You’ve got to be IN the band. You're amazing. Right Darren?
Are you into that Eamon? We can see that Eamon is very glad to be asked, but bluff little:
What kind of music are you going to be doing?
I don’t know yet. (CONTINUED)
You have to know what you’re going to play. What are you into?
I’m a futurist.
What does that mean?
Like no nostalgia. Not like your dad's band. Not looking backwards. Just forwards.
Cool. Like Depeche Mode?
(not knowing them) Okay.
Or Joy Division?
(bluffing) Right. Eamon sure knows his stuff.
Or Duran Duran. What do you think of them?

(beat, then parroting Brendan) The jury is out on which way those guys will go. They’re a lot of fun, and James Taylor is one of the most proficient bass players in the UK right now, giving them a funky edge. Silence. Eamon is impressed, even though Conor has got Jo Taylor’s name wrong.
JOHN Taylor.
Yea. John. Of course. They stand there, sizing each other up. (CONTINUED)
I‘1l be in the band. I'1l play guitar. And help write the songs. We can rehearse here because me da’s in Saint John Of Gods.
Is that a pub?
No, Darren. It’s where alcoholics go to get off drink and stop beating up their wives and kids.
Right.
And neighbors.
Okay.

And the police. INT. EAMON’S KITCHEN - MOMENTS LATER Conor, Eamon and Darren sit around the kitchen table continuing their plans. Eamon’s MOTHER (45), is pouring Cup-O-Soup into three bow in front of them, and giving them slices of bread. Eamon stroking a bunny on his knee.
Who’s going to be the manager?
Me.
Have you managed bands before?
No. (thinks) I’m just breaking into the market?
Nice. How are we going to cut things up?
I’1ll draw up contracts? EAMON’S MUM Do you need a pen? (CONTINUED)
Ma, we are trying to have a band meeting here? She smiles as she pours.

Gotta have everything straight first. Get everything down on paper. Otherwise you can get ripped off by the big record labels when they come a huntin’. That’s what me dad says. Eamon’s mum laughs conspicuously.
When do you want to rehearse? EAMON’S MUM Not the weekends. He’s got a job packing shelves in Quinnsworth on Saturdays. You’re not leaving that job. Not for any jaysis band.
How about Mondays and Wednesdays after school.
Sounds good. EAMON’S MUM That’s fine.
Now all we need is other musicians. Do either of you know any other musicians?
No. You?
No. Eamon? EAMON’S MUM He usually just plays on his own, don’t you son? She squeezes his shoulder.
Right, we can’t get any peace here. Let’s continue this meeting out the back. They get up, following Eamon out back. (CONTINUED )
EAMON’S MUM No smoking now!
Ma! How many times do I have to tell you? I don’t smoke! They exit.

The three of them stand in a VERY small shed. They are al smoking. They are continuing their plans. From the window at the kitchen where Eamon’s mum is washi up, she can plainly see smoke wafting out the window. She shrugs. Darren clicks his fingers.
There's a black guy in 3B?
So?
Be cool if he was in the band.
Why?
He’s the one colored guy in the whole school. Probably in Dublin! Having a Golliwog in the band would give us a real edge.
You can’t say Golliwog.
Why not?
Trust me. You just can’t. Darren looks to Eamon for this. Eamon shakes his head, agreeing with Conor. Darren shrugs.
Anyway what if he can’t play anything?
He’1l be able to play something. He’s black! (CONTINUED)

Close on a FLYER up on a notice board in school. It reads Futurist band forming. Looking for Bass player, drummer, and keyboard. Own instruments not essential, as we have them. Influences include DEPECHE MODE, DURAN DURAN and many more! Contact Management Solutions at 221 St. Teresa's Gardens. No telephone. Just call in.

location: A HOUSE ON A HOUSING ESTATE

text: Conor, Eamon and Darren knock on the door of a small hous a shitty housing estate. In a moment, an enormous, beauti woman answers the door. She speaks in a strong Nigerian accent, wearing colorful headgear and dress. They’ve neve seen anything like it.
Wow.
Can I help you?
Is this the house where the colored lad lives?
What do you think? How many black people do you think live on this shitting estate!? (beat) Do you know Ngig?
What is that?
My son! Do you know my son?
No. But we're in his school. And we're putting a band together. Does he play any instruments?
(opening the door wider) Why don’t you ask him yourself. They enter.
Does he speak English?  36. INT. NGIG’S SITTING ROOM - MOMENTS LATER The three lads stand in a small, tidy living space. In fr of them, NGIG (14), a black kid, stocky, well built.
(very slowly)
What the hell is wrong with him? When he speaks, he speaks in a tough, inner city Dublin accent.
Oh. You sound different from your ma?
‘Course I do, I’ve been here half me bleedin life. What did you expect.
Would you have any interest in being in a band? He clearly is.
Maybe. What kind of music are yous playing?

We're not 100 percent sure yet. But do you play any instruments? He is about to shake his head, when his mother interrupts NGIG’S MOTHER Of course he does. He’s black. Ngig looks doubtfully at his ma. She nods her head. Music starts up on the track. It’s sketchy, out of time, vaguely recognizable. It’s a bad cover version of RIO, by Duran Duran.
Song over. TRACK out from the flier. Two KIDS are writing down the number from the flier on the wall. They are identical twi rhythm section, GARRY and LARRY (14). (CONTINUED)

It is hard to read the number, as the poster is covered i array of Spunking Dick drawings. INT. EAMON’S LIVING ROOM - DAY Conor sings into a microphone. Eamon plays rhythm guitar. Garry fingers a bass guitar. His twin brother Larry sits behind the drum kit. Ngig cycles through sounds on an ear synthesizer. He has no real idea what he’s doing. Conor is hesitant and nervous. Though he can sing, he has zero presence. It’s chaos. They are all dressed in their school uniforms look awful. TRACK down to find a tape casette recorder on a chair in middle of them. It is RECORDING. The song ends.
Not bad.
Sounds great.
I think we sped up a little.
Really? We were shit.
Yeah, it’s a shit song. We should be a metal band.
It’s not the song. It’s us. It was all over the place. Let’s try it again.
Smoke break!
What?
Cool. I’m gasping for a smoke! They all run out. Eamon sighs, looking at Conor, the only other one who has left his station.  38.
ALL of the band are crammed into the shed smoking.
So what are we called? They think.
The Rabbits?
What is wrong with you and Rabbits??
I just love them. So fluffy. Those ears. Not a dog. Yet not quite a cat. And manageable shit. Just, the perfect pet.
I have an idea. What about “La vie”. Silence. Darren looks at him, witheringly.
What does that mean?
It French for “The Life”
What’s French for “That's not going to be the name of the band”?
(beat) “C'est nes pas le nom du groupe”
Right. There you go.
What about Sing Street. They think about this. Not bad.
I like that. INT. BRENDAN’S ROOM - NIGHT Song continues. (CONTINUED)

Pull out from Brendan's tape machine. Conor is playing hi brother his first demo tape. The tape reads “SING STREET” DEMO 1. If it sounded bad live this afternoon, it sounds worse played back on a small tape machine. Conor chews his nails in anticipation of his big brother' response. Brendan finally ejects the tape before it’s ove
This is BAD. And there’s nothing as bad as bad music. And you must never play this again. To Conor's surprise, he begins unspooling the tape, pulli it out in a pile at his feet.
You know you can record over tapes?
No no. All evidence of this day must be destroyed. He finally bins the tape.
That’s a novelty act. You want to get the girl right?
What?
(shouting, impatient) The Girl! That’s what this is about? Right?
(thinking) Oh. Yes. The girl. Right. Okay.
Right. So you’re going to get her with someone else’s art? Are you kidding me?
I suppose. But we’re just starting out. We need to learn how to play.
Play? PLAY? You don’t need to know how to play! You think the Sex Pistols knew how to play? Who are you, Steely Dan? (CONTINUED)
Brendan is coming into his own. He leaves his chair, paci the room. Pulling different records from his collection. now has the first project of his adult life: his brother.
You have to learn how to NOT play. That’s rock n roll. And that takes practice. (beat) And you’re not a covers band!
Really?

Every school has a covers band. Every wedding. Every pub. And in every covers band there’s a middle aged man who never knows if he could have made it because he never had the balls to write a song for someone. Rock n Roll is a risk. You risk being ridiculed. Conor thinks about this.
I don’t know how to write a song. Brendan now has a large pile of records in his arms. He points at the door.
Close the door. And sit down.
Really? I have school in the morning.
THIS... is school. Conor closes the door. Sits down. It’s going to be a long night.

sONG 1 A song is formed... INT. EAMON’S LIVING ROOM - DAY Conor and Eamon are alone in the rehearsal room. Conor reading from a little notebook of scrawled thoughts and pictures. Eamon sits on the edge of the couch with an acoustic guitar. (CONTINUED)
(reading) “Well she’s standing on the corner. Like an angel in disguise. And I want to try and warn her, but She’s got dangerous eyes.”
Dangerous eyes. I like that. What does that mean?
I don’t know.
What’s this song about Conor?
It’s like, when you don’t know someone, they’re more interesting. They can be anything you want them to be. It’s like you know them better, when you don’t know them. You know?
No that doesn’t make any sense. What’s it called?
“The Riddle of the model”
Epic. What about a rhythm like this. Eamon plays a chord. A funky rhythm.

Nice. Slow it down a little. Conor tries this lyric over it. Eamon drops to an F, and starts to sound like something. They smile at the change. Conor takes out a pen from his school bag, adding a lyric Eamon continues to play. We start to see how this might work- Conor the director/lyricist/visionary, Eamon the pragmatic musical prodigy. The sound of their first song coming together plays over following scenes. Just guitar and voice for now.
Song over. (CONTINUED)

Conor sits at the back of Irish class. The TEACHER reads SAYERS while sitting behind his desk. Conor writes feveri in his notebook, looking out the window for inspiration. teacher calls a BOY up to his desk, and slaps him, really hard across the face. ( SCENE 41 INTENTIONALLY DELETED )
Conor writes in his bed. His parents rowing on the corrid off.
(off, muffled) That’s funny, coming from you!

Keep your bloody voice down! Two doors slam, separately. He listens out, then continue writing. INT. EAMON’S LIVING ROOM - DAY Song over. The song is really coming together, as Conor and Eamon ja it. Though complete opposites, this combination of songwriters is coming together. Through the window behind them, the rest of the band are playing football in the garden. Conor taps on the window, waving at them to come and give it a spin. They run in. INT. EAMON’S LIVING ROOM - LATER Now the FULL band play the song. And it sounds pretty goo Conor is still a little shy of his own voice, and is froz at the microphone. Eamon gestures for him to enjoy it. But he just smiles an stays static. Again, the tape recorder records it on the chair in the middle of them.
Song over. The song plays over as Conor walks across the street. Fro his satchel he produces a casette tape as he meets the GI standing on her stoop smoking. He hands her the tape. (CONTINUED)
What’s this now?
That’s the song. I mentioned it to you.
Oh yeah. The song. You’re the kid in the band! That’s cool.

You should probably learn the lyrics. So you can lip sync. We're shooting down the lane at the back of Quinnsworth. This Saturday. At 12 o'clock. See you there. He nods, not waiting for a response. She blows smoke, watching him go. Then she looks at the tape in her hand.
By moonlight, Conor, Darren and Eamon peel back a sheet o corrugated metal at the back of school. This allows them gap to slip through into the yard.
Darren opens a little back door with a key. They are in.

The three of them sneak down a basement corridor. Conor guides them with a clunky bicycle lamp. They arrive at a door. A handwritten sign says “Audio Visual Room”. Darren tries numerous keys until he gets the right one. T open it.
(with the flair of a master criminal) Gentlemen, I give you the Audio Visual Department....

This is hardly a room at all. More like a broom closet. Conor's torch reveals a steel shelving unit, bare, except the camera and VCR machine on the top shelf. And three or four VHS tapes. They start taking it down.
The three of them run back across the road by moonlight laughing. Music plays over.

The band are setting up their instruments on a rainy morn They are down a little laneway at the back of a row of sh Piles of rubbish, old bins, and an abandoned car. It’s overcast and depressing. And cold. Their guitar amps and drum kit look pretty small out in t open.

It looks like loads of gear back home, doesn’t it? And yet it looks shit here. Conor is setting up the video camera across from them on tripod. He looks through the viewfinder. It does look shi He checks his watch.
Where is this chick?
(worried) I don’t know.
Did everyone bring some clothes? They start rooting through plastic bags stuffed with clot from home. Larry holds up a pair of flares. Garry, a child’s cowboy outfit.
Who the hell brought a cowboy outfit?
Me. It’s all I could find.
No one dresses as a cowboy in a band!
There’s a cowboy in The Village People. (CONTINUED)
Yeah. And Adam Ant.
Adam Ant is a highway man.
So we can have a highway man, but not a cowboy? Are you mentally ill?
So what did you bring then? Hard cut.

Conor is dressed as a low-budget New Romantic. A mash-up ideas from a cross section of TV. Nothing quite works. He wearing sunglasses, bangles, his father’s long overcoat w the sleeves rolled up, and a blouse that definitely belon to his mum. Eamon is dressed in his Dad’s show-band uniform. A purple velvet suit that is way too big for him. He’s a little Au Powers.
It’s me Da’s showband outfit. Garry, Larry and Ngig are unimpressed. Darren isn’t sure.
Is this a gay band?
Coming from the one who wants to look like The Village People.

What’s gay about The Village People?? As the others squabble, Conor’s attention is drawn to the of the lane, where Raphina has just appeared. He smiles. She approaches carrying a large bag. She looks great, in a huge Angora sweater, pencil skirt and high he
Hello all. Sorry I’m late. I was out last night. At a night club. Still recovering. She takes off her sunglasses, dramatically, looking them and down. (CONTINUED)
Jesus Christ. What in God’s name are ye all wearing?
Yeah, we’re just working that out. Maybe you can help.
Who’s your wardrobe person? Stevie Wonder?
We don’t have a wardrobe person.
Right. Who’s the camera man. Maybe he can make some of this work.
Em... We don’t really have...
I’m the camera man.
I thought you were the producer.
AND camera man. Saving money all the way. Conor takes her by the elbow, walking her out of earshot little.
What did you think of the song?
I liked it. It’s the only reason I’m here. Did you write it?
Pretty much. Eamon wrote most of the music.
So you wrote the lyrics? They’re cool. Who are they about?
Just a girl, I see her about.
You know you’ve got really good cheek bones? (CONTINUED)
What?
Yeah. Look at you. Can I do your makeup?
Really?
Yeah. This light is going to be really harsh on camera. You should totally take the edge off it. I’m actually wearing some make up right now. She's wearing a_lot of makeup.
In fact, guys! You should ALL wear makeup. The band turn around.
Let’s get one thing straight. I am NOT wearing any makeup.
Relax. You’re not even in the band.
Yeah, thank God!
I am in the band. And yet I’m not wearing makeup.
Why not? You've got great lips.
Piss off would you?
Whatever. Those who actually care about how their band look and want to do this half-properly, queue over here.
Who’s saying we don’t care about the band? This band is my life!
You've been in it for three days. (CONTINUED)
Alright, stop rowing.
Bitch. Raphina sets up her stall on a rubbish bin, taking out he makeup kit. Conor sits down on an upturned box and she be applying his make up.
Who is this chick anyway? She’s here two minutes and she’s threatening to break the band up!
Shut up Garry.
Bleedin Yoko Ono.

All of the band are now wearing makeup. It’s a little ful on, but they look sort of cool. Conor directs Darren as to what the shot will be, referri to his notebook. Darren looks through the viewfinder.
Okay, so we’re playing here. Raphina is standing over there, against the wall. I go up to her. Start singing to her. Make sure to pan up to her eyes, when I sing “She's got Dangerous eyes”.
I think a zoom would be better.
Okay. A zoom, whatever.
What if I have little lightening flashes on my eye lids when I close them?
Can you do that?
I can try.
Cool. So then, for the chorus, you walk off, and I follow. (MORE) (CONTINUED)
Circling you like when he’s following her in Thriller. Do you think you can keep the camera steady, Darren?
What do you think?
Okay, so then I follow her up the lane. Keeping behind her. Then we'll go around and get that angle in front.

Love it! EXT. LANEWAY - MOMENT’S LATER Conor presses PLAY on the tape machine. It is plugged int small speaker. He signals to Darren to start filming. The runs back to the band, who have started miming to the son Raphina is standing against the wall. Conor approaches he Darren following. Conor starts lip syncing to the song:

“Well she’s standing on the corner. Like an angel in disguise. And I'd really like to warn her. But she’s got dangerous eyes.” Darren crash zooms into her eyes. Raphina closes them, sh has little lightening flashes on her lids.

“Well she tells me she’s a model. Of international reputation. She’s lightening in a bottle. But there's a stipulation...” She sets off and Conor follows her. Darren walks backward front of them. Conor yells “Cut”, and makes some adjustments. Ngig has m his synthesiser and stand about three feet to try get in back of Conor’s shot.
Cool. How does it look Darren?
Pretty epic. It’s hard keeping focus on that zoom. And Ngig, stop moving into the back of his shot. (CONTINUED)
I haven't moved an inch!
You started about three foot that way!
It was windy.
And it’s not too shaky when you're following us?
No, it’s grand.

Okay, take 2! FIRST VIDEO. SHOT ON ACTUAL EARLY VHS. Here we see their actual results, edited crudely together INTRO: Some zooms into hands playing instruments. Keyboar Bass. Guitar. Ngig is wearing leather gloves. FIRST VERSE: Conor breaks away from the band, singing int camera in front of Raphina. Ngig edges into his shot. Four quick shots of each band member turning their heads looking into camera. Raphina signing autographs for the band members, over the line “She has an international reputation”.
Raphina breaks away, walking down the laneway. Conor walk around her, singing to her, ala Michael in Thriller. But Darren's camera work is RIDICULOUSLY shaky. Like sea sick inducing.

The band are using the abandoned car as their set. Some sitting on the roof. Some on the boot (or hood, for our American colleagues), and others in the body of the car. Raphina is standing on the sidewalk. Conor gets out of th car, offering her a lift. She sits in. Up front, Conor is “driving” Raphina. She looks into came for the last line, and mouths “The riddle of the model” End. (CONTINUED)

The group laugh as they prepare to watch playback through viewfinder. But this moment is interrupted when Barry Bray appears up laneway. He is walking with an unshaven man in his mid- thirties who is drinking a can of beer. A friend, or brot maybe. They are carrying a few plastic bags of shopping.
(under his breath) Oh shit. Barry and THE MAN pass them, THE MAN slowing down to chec out what’s going on. He looks like he’s had a few cans already.
It’s just kids filming something. What are you filming lads?
A video for a band. Hi Barry. Barry shrugs.
Are these in your school, Barry? Whatever has come over Barry, he is less confident in the presence of THE MAN. Less of a bully.
They're wearing bleedin make up! Jaysus lads, are yous making a movie, is it? His laugh turns into a coughing fit. His tattooed hands o his mouth as he coughs.
A video for a band.
Why don’t you get in the band Barry? Hah! Dress up and all. You’d be bleedin’ great. He starts laughing at the idea of Barry in costume.
Ah piss off. But he doesn’t like this. He hits him a slap on the side of his head. It’s a sucker punch, and totally out of proportion. (CONTINUED)
What did you say? The mood has suddenly changed. Barry hardly flinches, but can see his eyes are watering up. The MAN calms down. Lig a cigarette. Barry catches eyes with Conor, who looks away.
See yous boys. Good luck. See yous at the Oscars! Come on Barry. Barry follows behind. They turn the corner up ahead. The others don’t know what that was.

Knackers. Come on. Never mind them. Darren presses play on the machine as the others watch. B Conor’s attention is momentarily taken by Barry, who make throat-slitting gesture back to Conor. All the colour dra from Conor's face. ( SCENE 55 INTENTIONALLY DELETED ) ( SCENE 56 INTENTIONALLY DELETED )

Raphina diverts his attention back to the viewfinder. On screen, Conor begins singing. Raphina smiles at him. She grabs his hand in excitement as she appears on screen. An doesn’t let go. Conor looks down at his hand in hers.
Conor is cycling his rusty racer through the city. Raphin sitting on the cross bar, holding on to the handlebars, enjoying the wind in her hair.
So where do you live?
Not far from the school. Harcourt Terrace?
Oh, by the canal. You grew up there? (CONTINUED)
Yeah. Though we might be moving. My parents are broke. That’s why they sent me to that school.
Yeah, I wondered about that. You’re a bit posh for around here! She laughs.
Speak for yourself. Your house is massive! She is silent.
And my parents are probably splitting up.
That’s sad. You doing okay with it?

Oh yeah. It’s sort of intense being around them. They’1l probably get separate flats. We’ll live between two places. Me and my brother. Which will be cool. I’m like “Guys, split up, you’re killing each other”. He is experimenting with this. It is not how he feels abo it at all.
A bit like an American movie. You'll be all complicated and divorced and sophisticated.
(bluffing) A bit, yeah. He doesn’t quite know what she means, as they pull up out her house across from the school. She jumps off the bike.
Jesus, all that drama! I’m glad I don’t have parents.
Right. He has no idea what she means. Though intrigued, he is po enough not to ask. (CONTINUED)
A Ford Granada screams into the street, and skids up besi them. The window winds down, and a smiling man (22) is at wheel. Music blaring, smoking a cigarette.
Hey baby.
Hi. This is Evan Adams.
Word.
How do you do.
This is Conor, the singer in the band I mentioned.
Ah! Cool. She played me your song. Good vibes. Bitta Duran Duran in there, little bitta New Romance. What style would you say you are?
I’m a futurist.
Epic. See you in the future then. You ready, baby?
